nodes.text: Implanted in a user's palm and fingers and linked to their brainstem, the CAAF-2 system cybernetic avionics interface produced by TaggeCo allowed pilots to connect with the avionics and flight control systems of airspeeders and starships at digital levels. While the interface did not eliminate the need for manual control of vessels, it did significantly improve a pilot's reaction time and helped to provide instantaneous feedback from the ship's computer. The cost of the CAAF-2 was 10,000 credits.

The CAAF-2 system cybernetic avionics was first mentioned in the new Star Wars canon in Gadgets and Gear, a 2019 supplement to Fantasy Flight Games' series of Star Wars Roleplaying products. It was first mentioned in the Star Wars Legends continuity in Suns of Fortune, a 2014 supplement to Fantasy Flight Games' series of Star Wars: Edge of the Empire roleplaying games.
